content:
There was nothing in the "Mail and News Accounts" section. I'm sorry it's being so complicated

It's not complicated. So you're just trying to set up an existing account in Thunderbird. That wasn't obvious from your OP. It helps being precise.

Make sure cookies are allowed in Thunderbird. Don't use a VPN when attempting to authenticate. Also make sure no software is occupying TCP port 80 on localhost, e.g. like a local web server.

In Settings - General, uncheck the option 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'.

I changed the password to an "app password".

With OAuth authentication you must use the main account password, not an app password.

Having said that, it is a really bad idea to post your password to a public forum. So you want to remove those screenshots with the password.

content:
RonB1949 said
My original post said "I have tried many times to get Thunderbird to connect to my Gmail account. " I have changed the screenshot - thanks for pointing that out. I'm not using a VPN. I can't see how to allow cookies in Thunderbird - it's a program on my PC, not a website. </blockqauote> So is you browser, it also has an option in settings to allow or disallow cookies.
I tried with the main account password - that didn't work but I'll try it again. I was using xampp which may have been using port 80. I have stopped xampp. The option 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'. is unchecked - I never checked it. I'll have changed the password.

I would guess we have an antivirus problem. The settings you posted way back were correct. An attempt to connect using them should initiate a series of web pages from Google asking for your password and permission for Mozilla Thunderbird to access your email, contacts etc at Google. Do you get these "Popups"? I have frequently seen folk on this forum complain about them and either close them or ignore them and then complain that Thunderbird is not getting their mail, so I have to ask. Are you one of them.

What antivirus are you using? While a password is included in the account setup, it is not used at all in an oauth authentication process which must be used for google gmail. You would be just as well leaving it out entirely.

It's now stuck saying "Looking up configuration. Probing server" . It's ok if you want to leave it for now. Thanks for your efforts so far.

There should be no server probing going on. Thunderbird should lookup the settings here https://autoconfig.thunderbird.net/v1.1/gmail.com and use them. That there is probing going on would indicate a firewall issue blocking that lookup.

We come back to my assumption you have an antivirus issue as most of those these days come with these fancy anti phishing and scam modules that actively block the probing. However as I said Thunderbird should not get to that point because it looked up the settings. For that to fail indicates a software firewall issue another antivirus component. I have a pet hate going on with Norton as I have a friend that uses it and have never managed to set up an account on his system without disabling whole chunks of it. Something called SONAR blocked the new account wizard, despite it not having anything to do with email according to Norton. It has a VPN component with a longstanding habit or just re-enabling itself. Google/Gmail does not do well with a VPN as christ1 alluded. Essentially if you have an antivirus other than Microsoft defender it is suspect
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Capisco che tu le impostazioni le conosca, ma io no... Se puoi riportare le informazioni che ti ho chiesto, altrimenti non so che dirti.
creator: @next

content:
hai ragione, non posso farti adesso lo screen, ma la configurazione corrisponde a questa: Le informazioni richieste definiscono i dati di connessione del server. In particolare:

Server posta in arrivo: mbox.cert.legalmail.it Server posta in uscita: sendm.cert.legalmail.it Le porte utilizzate, sono rispettivamente:

Server posta in arrivo (IMAP): 993 Server posta in uscita (SMTP): 465

Per entrambi i server ho selezionato la modalità crittografica SSL/TLS e scelto l'opzione Password normale nella sezione autenticazione. Inoltre come Impostazioni server sono attivi i seguenti flag:

Controlla nuovi messaggi all’avvio Controlla nuovi messaggi ogni 1 minuto Consentire la notifica immediata da parte del server quando arriva un nuovo messaggio

l'antivirus è attivo da sempre per cui non credo che dipenda da quello, forse qualche aggiornamento di windows oppure qualche intervento sul protocollo TLS...grazie mille
creator: roberta.rossetti

content:
Da quello che posso capire le impostazioni sono corrette. Rimane il dubbio sull'antivirus, se potessi fare un test disattivandolo temporaneamente (anche solo il modulo che controlla la posta elettronica) potrebbe essere utile.

Se però escludiamo anche l'antivirus, non c'è molto altro da fare. Potrebbe esserci una incompatibilità tra Thunderbird ed il tuo fornitore. Purtroppo non sono cliente di Legalmail per cui prove specifiche non ne posso fare.

content: This forum is supported by users like you, individuals who give of their free time to assist others. If you need a direct response to your questions, you should consider an email client that charges a hefty fee instead of using Thunderbird, which is FREE. And, the scenario you posted has no relevance to Thunderbird, but to your email provider. All thunderbird does is relay the messages from email provider to you. Thunderbird does not check passwords, does not issue recovery codes.

content:
johannes said
1 Show remote content in this message to show remote content just for this particular message. 2 Edit remote content preferences… to display remote content by default (see next section). 3 Allow remote content from <website> to show the remote content stored on this site. 4 Allow remote content from all <n> origins listed above adds all the n websites listed above to the remote content exception list. 5 Allow remote content from <email address> adds the sender email address to the remote content exceptions list. Q1 How do option 1 and option 4 differ exactly? Q2 What will option 5 do exactly. Would it be the same as option 4 but also allow future, currently unknown <website>, for emails from the same <email address>?

1. (1) allows all remote content for all sites listed for that message only. (4) allows remote content from all sites listed in (1) for any future messages.

2. I believe so.

content:
I am sorry to sound thick. But I have no idea what you are on about. What does seeing if there is an attachment have to do with attachment options?

Attachments, when there are any appear at the bottom of the message screen as shown below

This attachment pane appears if there is an attachment. As the file names are set by the sender, Thunderbird needs to know nothing about the file type to receive an attachment. It will remember what application you decide to open the type type in, that is how the external helper application list is grown from the PDF entry that exists because Thunderbird handles them internally.

Just as you have no need to know anything about what is inside a package you sign for at your door. Thunderbird does not care anything about attachments. I does not even decode the MIME text that arrives representing the attachment into a file until you decide to do something with it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:

content:
Each folder has it's own settings as to sort order. Once you modify the default then it is up to you to choose when and what folders you use it on.

krtemp-online said
Why aren't all folders / lists adhering to the set choice in settings.

Perhaps you did not change the default and apply it to all existing folders.
